extracted_ttps.description: Attacker used a proxy for command and control
Attacker used PowerShell to execute a command and connect to a C&C server
Attacker used PowerShell to execute a command and contact the C&C server
Seedworm uses PowerShell to run commands, download payloads, traverse compromised networks, and carry out reconnaissance
Seedworm uses Venom Proxy, a multi-hop proxy tool, for command and control
Attacker used a proxy tool
Attacker used PowerShell for execution
Attacker used a custom keylogger and Venom Proxy hacktool, which may have been executed by the user
Detected PowerShell activity via NLP pattern matching
Attacker used Windows Scripting Files (WSF) and AnyDesk, which may be used for application window discovery
Attacker modified the Windows registry to store the C&C URL
Seedworm uses SimpleHelp to gain access to the user's device, potentially for credential dumping
Seedworm uses SimpleHelp to constantly run as a system service, allowing for persistence
Seedworm carries out reconnaissance, which may involve collecting data from the local system
Seedworm uses SimpleHelp to execute commands on a device with administrator privileges
Seedworm uses custom keylogger and other tools that may require user execution
Seedworm downloads payloads, which may involve transferring tools into the compromised network
Attacker used a scheduled task to launch the MuddyC2Go malware
Attacker used MuddyC2Go launcher, which was sideloaded by jabswitch.exe
Attacker used WMI to launch the SimpleHelp installer
Attacker used SimpleHelp and AnyDesk remote access tools
Seedworm traverses compromised networks, which may involve using remote services
Attacker collected data from the local system using a keylogger
Attacker used WMI to get drive info
Attacker used user execution to run commands
Attacker used an application to discover windows
Attacker used a custom keylogging tool
Detected Create or Modify System Process activity via NLP pattern matching
Attacker dumped SAM hives
Detected Application Layer Protocol activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Command and Scripting Interpreter activity via NLP pattern matching
Attacker used WMI for execution
Detected Windows Management Instrumentation activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected OS Credential Dumping activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Network Service Discovery activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Archive Collected Data activity via NLP pattern matching
Attacker used phishing to gain initial access
Detected Scheduled Task/Job activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Input Capture activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Registry Run Keys activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Remote Desktop Protocol activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Proxy Command and Control Detection
rules.description: Detects potential proxy command and control activity based on network connections to known proxy IP addresses
falsepositives: Legitimate traffic to proxy servers used by organizations for internet access
Network connections to proxy servers used for security testing or research purposes

rules.title: PowerShell Execution with Invoke-WebRequest
rules.description: Detects the use of PowerShell to execute a command and connect to a C&C server using Invoke-WebRequest
falsepositives: Legitimate use of PowerShell for administrative tasks
PowerShell scripts used by system administrators for automation

rules.title: Detection: User Execution
rules.description: Attacker used a custom keylogger and Venom Proxy hacktool, which may have been executed by the user

rules.title: Detection: PowerShell
rules.description: Detected PowerShell activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Application Window Discovery via WSF and AnyDesk
rules.description: Detects the use of Windows Scripting Files (WSF) and AnyDesk for application window discovery
falsepositives: Legitimate use of WSF for automation

rules.title: Modify Registry for Persistence
rules.description: Detects modification of Windows registry to store C&C URL for persistence

rules.title: Credential Dumping via SimpleHelp
rules.description: Detects the use of SimpleHelp for potential credential dumping
falsepositives: Legitimate use of SimpleHelp for remote support or management

rules.title: Create or Modify System Process via SimpleHelp
rules.description: Detects the creation or modification of system processes using SimpleHelp, which can be used for persistence by adversaries like Seedworm.

rules.title: Data from Local System Detection
rules.description: Detects reconnaissance activity by collecting data from the local system

rules.title: Detection: Command and Scripting Interpreter
rules.description: Seedworm uses SimpleHelp to execute commands on a device with administrator privileges

rules.title: Detection: Ingress Tool Transfer
rules.description: Seedworm downloads payloads, which may involve transferring tools into the compromised network

rules.title: Detection: Signed Binary Proxy Execution
rules.description: Attacker used MuddyC2Go launcher, which was sideloaded by jabswitch.exe

rules.title: Detection: System Information Discovery
rules.description: Attacker used WMI to launch the SimpleHelp installer

rules.title: Remote Access Tools Detection
rules.description: Detects the use of SimpleHelp and AnyDesk remote access tools
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative use of SimpleHelp or AnyDesk
False positives may occur if these tools are used by administrators for remote support

rules.title: Remote Services Lateral Movement Detection
rules.description: Detects potential lateral movement using remote services

rules.title: Detection of Input Capture via Custom Keylogging Tool
rules.description: Identifies the use of a custom keylogging tool to capture input, aligned with MITRE ATT&CK technique T1056 - Input Capture
falsepositives: Legitimate applications using GetAsyncKeyState for non-malicious purposes
Gaming software or accessibility tools that simulate keyboard input

rules.title: Detection: Windows Management Instrumentation
rules.description: Attacker used WMI for execution

rules.title: Detection: Windows Management Instrumentation
rules.description: Detected Windows Management Instrumentation activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Detection: OS Credential Dumping
rules.description: Detected OS Credential Dumping activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Network Service Discovery via Command Line
rules.description: Detects Network Service Discovery activity via command line patterns

rules.title: Archive Collected Data Detection
rules.description: Detects Archive Collected Data activity via process creation events

rules.title: Detection: Phishing
rules.description: Attacker used phishing to gain initial access

rules.title: Scheduled Task/Job Detection
rules.description: Detects Scheduled Task/Job activity via NLP pattern matching
falsepositives: Legitimate system administrators creating or running scheduled tasks
Third-party software using the 'schtasks' command or 'taskeng'/'taskhost' process

rules.title: Registry Run Keys Detection
rules.description: Detects Registry Run Keys activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Remote Desktop Protocol Detection
rules.description: Detects Remote Desktop Protocol activity via process creation and network connections

attacks.description: Sets the system-wide proxy server to 127.0.0.1:8080 using netsh
attacks.expected_behavior: The system will start using the specified proxy server for HTTP requests.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to set a proxy for a web request and then makes a request to example.com
attacks.expected_behavior: The PowerShell script sets a proxy for the current session and then uses it to make a web request to example.com.

attacks.description: Adds a registry key to set the proxy server to 127.0.0.1:8080 for the current user
attacks.expected_behavior: The user's internet settings will be updated to use the specified proxy server.

attacks.command: sudo sysctl -w net.ipv4.ip_forward=1; sudo iptables -t nat -A POSTROUTING -o eth0 -j MASQUERADE
attacks.description: Enable IP forwarding and set up NAT to allow proxying
attacks.expected_behavior: The system will start forwarding IP packets and NAT will be enabled, allowing it to act as a proxy.

attacks.description: Set up a SOCKS proxy using SSH
attacks.expected_behavior: A SOCKS proxy will be established on port 8080, allowing the system to proxy traffic through the specified SSH server.

attacks.description: Use a SOCKS proxy to access a website
attacks.expected_behavior: The curl command will access the specified website through the SOCKS proxy, demonstrating the use of a proxy for command and control.

attacks.description: Basic PowerShell command execution
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes a simple PowerShell command that prints 'Hello World' to the console, demonstrating basic command execution capability.

attacks.description: Intermediate command downloading a file using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a file from a specified URL to the temporary directory, simulating a potential C&C server communication or malware download scenario.

attacks.description: Advanced encoded command execution
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes an encoded command, demonstrating how an attacker might hide malicious commands. The command decodes a Base64 string to 'Hello world' and then executes it, showcasing advanced techniques for command obfuscation.

attacks.description: Basic command to test PowerShell execution on Linux
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in the $env:TEMP directory with the content 'Hello World'

attacks.description: Intermediate command to test PowerShell execution with web request on Linux
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads the content from http://example.com and saves it to a file named test.txt in the $env:TEMP directory

attacks.description: Advanced command to test PowerShell execution with file compression on Linux
attacks.expected_behavior: Compresses the file test.txt in the $env:TEMP directory and saves it as test.zip in the same directory

attacks.description: Basic command that executes a benign file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file in the temp directory and opens it

attacks.description: Intermediate command that uses PowerShell to execute a command
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file in the temp directory and opens it using PowerShell

attacks.description: Advanced command that uses encoding to execute a command
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file in the temp directory and opens it using encoded PowerShell command

attacks.description: Basic command to write a test string to a file in the user's home directory, demonstrating basic user execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test_file.txt in the user's home directory with the content 'test_string'.

attacks.description: Intermediate command that creates a directory and then writes a test string to a file within that directory, showing slightly more complex user execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a directory named test_dir in the user's home directory and a file named test_file.txt within it with the content 'test_string'.

attacks.description: Advanced command demonstrating user execution by creating a hidden file, changing its permissions, and then writing to it, simulating more sophisticated malicious activity.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a hidden file named .test_file in the user's home directory, changes its permissions to readable, writable, and executable only by the owner, and then writes 'test_string' to it.

attacks.description: Download a Base64-encoded PowerShell script, decode it, save to disk, and execute locally
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a Base64-encoded script from a local server, decodes it into a .ps1 file in /tmp, removes the encoded file, and executes the decoded script. Simulates staged payload delivery.

attacks.description: Execute a simple inline PowerShell command using Invoke-Expression (IEX)
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a test message via an inline executed command. Demonstrates use of IEX for code execution, commonly seen in obfuscated attacks.

attacks.description: List all running processes to discover application windows
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of all running processes

attacks.description: Get a list of all running processes including their main window titles
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of running processes with their main window titles

attacks.description: Find a specific process (notepad in this case) and its main window title
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays the process name and main window title of the specified process if running

attacks.description: Lists all windows being managed by the window manager.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of managed windows, including their IDs and titles.

attacks.description: Displays information about all windows on the screen, including their IDs, positions, and sizes.
attacks.expected_behavior: Provides detailed information about each window, which can be used for application window discovery.

attacks.description: Searches for windows with the class 'Firefox' and returns their IDs.
attacks.expected_behavior: Returns the IDs of all Firefox windows, demonstrating how to discover specific application windows.

attacks.command: reg add HKCU\Software\Test /v TestValue /t REG_SZ /d TestData /f
attacks.description: Add a new registry key with a test value
attacks.expected_behavior: The registry key 'HKCU\Software\Test' will be created with the value 'TestData'

attacks.description: Silently import registry settings from a file
attacks.expected_behavior: The registry settings in the file 'test.reg' will be imported silently

attacks.description: Use PowerShell to create a new registry key and add a test value
attacks.expected_behavior: The registry key 'HKCU\Software\Test' will be created with the value 'TestData'

attacks.description: Modify a user's autostart configuration to add a malicious entry, simulating registry modification for persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new file named test.desktop will be created in the user's autostart directory, which can be used to execute commands or applications upon login.

attacks.description: Append a command to the system-wide profile file to execute upon user login, simulating a registry modification for persistence that requires admin privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: The string 'test_string' will be appended to the /etc/profile file, which can lead to the execution of commands or setup of environment variables system-wide upon user login.

attacks.description: Lists all user accounts on the system, which can be a preliminary step for credential dumping.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of user accounts.

attacks.description: Attempts to list user accounts in the domain, which could be used for credential dumping in a domain environment.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of domain user accounts if the command is run with sufficient privileges.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to list local user accounts, which can be part of a credential dumping process.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of local user accounts with their names and descriptions.

attacks.description: Search for password occurrences in /etc/ directory and subdirectories
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists files containing the string 'password'

attacks.description: Display the contents of the passwd file, which contains user information
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays user accounts on the system

attacks.description: Attempt to crack passwords using John the Ripper (requires John installation and assumes /etc/passwd is accessible)
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to crack system passwords

attacks.command: sc.exe create SimpleHelp binPath= "cmd.exe /c whoami > %TEMP%\simplehelp.log 2>&1" start= auto
attacks.description: Creates a Windows service named 'SimpleHelp' that runs cmd.exe on startup, logging output to a temporary file. Simulates persistence via service installation.
attacks.expected_behavior: Service 'SimpleHelp' is created and set to start automatically. On system boot or manual start, it runs cmd.exe, executes 'whoami', and logs output to %TEMP%\simplehelp.log. No network activity or payload execution occurs.

attacks.command: sc.exe config SimpleHelp binPath= "cmd.exe /c ping 127.0.0.1 -n 5 > NUL && echo Service running > %TEMP%\simplehelp_running.txt" obj= LocalSystem
attacks.description: Modifies the existing 'SimpleHelp' service to run as LocalSystem and execute a benign command that simulates periodic activity.
attacks.expected_behavior: The 'SimpleHelp' service binary path is updated to run a delayed command that writes a status file to %TEMP%. When started, it runs under LocalSystem and creates the file simplehelp_running.txt. No actual persistence is added if service does not exist.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "mkdir '$env:TEMP\\_simplehelp' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; $servicePath = '$env:TEMP\\_simplehelp\\service.bat'; Set-Content -Path $servicePath -Value 'cmd.exe /c echo [$(date)] Service started >> $env:TEMP\\_simplehelp\\log.txt' -Force; sc.exe create SimpleHelpSvc binPath= 'cmd.exe /c $servicePath' start= delayed-auto"
attacks.description: Creates a temporary script and registers it as a delayed-auto-start service using sc.exe via PowerShell, demonstrating intermediate persistence setup.
attacks.expected_behavior: A directory %TEMP%\_simplehelp is created, a batch script is written to log execution timestamps, and a service 'SimpleHelpSvc' is created to run it at startup with delayed start. The service will not start automatically in current session but is configured for future boots.

attacks.command:
echo '[Unit]
Description=Benign Background Service
[Service]
ExecStart=/bin/sh -c "while true; do sleep 60; done"
Restart=always
[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target' > /etc/systemd/system/benign.service && systemctl daemon-reload && systemctl enable benign.service && systemctl start benign.service
attacks.description: Creates a basic systemd service that runs a harmless infinite sleep loop for persistence testing.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new systemd service named 'benign.service' is created, enabled at boot, and started. It runs a loop sleeping for 60 seconds indefinitely.

attacks.command:
PAYLOAD=$(echo 'bash -c "while true; do sleep 45; done"' | base64 -w0) && echo '[Unit]
Description=Encoded Persistence
[Service]
ExecStart=/bin/sh -c "echo ${PAYLOAD} | base64 -d | /bin/bash"
Restart=always
[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target' > /etc/systemd/system/encoded.service && systemctl daemon-reload && systemctl enable encoded.service && systemctl start encoded.service
attacks.description: Creates a systemd service that decodes and executes a base64-encoded command for stealthier persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: A systemd service is created that decodes and runs a base64-encoded bash command (harmless sleep loop), enabling stealthier persistence with restart on failure.

attacks.description: Collects detailed system configuration (OS, hardware, hotfixes)
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs system information including OS version, installed updates, and hardware specs to stdout.

attacks.description: Aggregates user privileges, network config, and local accounts into temp file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates %TEMP%\userinfo.txt containing current user context, network interfaces, and local user accounts.

attacks.command: echo System Info: > %TEMP%\sysdata.txt & hostname >> %TEMP%\sysdata.txt & certutil -encode %TEMP%\sysdata.txt %TEMP%\sysdata.b64 & del %TEMP%\sysdata.txt -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue
attacks.description: Encodes collected hostname/system data to base64 then deletes original
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates base64-encoded %TEMP%\sysdata.b64 containing hostname and placeholder text, then deletes plaintext file.

attacks.description: Collects and displays system information such as the kernel name, hostname, kernel version, and more.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays system information to the console.

attacks.description: Displays the contents of the passwd file, which contains user account information.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays user account information to the console.

attacks.description: Lists the files and directories in the /home directory, displaying detailed information about each.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists files and directories in /home with detailed information.

attacks.description: Creates a local user account using net.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a new local user 'testuser' with specified password. Requires admin privileges to modify user accounts.

attacks.description: Creates a scheduled task running as SYSTEM to write test file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a scheduled task named 'UpdateCheck' that writes a test file to TEMP directory. Runs with SYSTEM privileges.

attacks.description: Adds registry entry via encoded PowerShell to execute command at startup
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates 'TestUpdate' registry entry in HKLM Run key to write test file to TEMP on startup. Requires admin for HKLM modification.

attacks.description: Basic execution of a command through the shell interpreter using pipe input.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will execute 'id' via /bin/sh and output the current user's identity to stdout.

attacks.description: Intermediate command using bash to search for processes running as root.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists all running processes and filters for those containing 'root' in the command line. Does not modify system state.

attacks.description: Advanced command that adds a cron job via stdin to execute a command every 5 minutes, demonstrating persistence using scripting interpreter.
attacks.expected_behavior: Installs a user-level cron job that writes a timestamp to /tmp/cron.log every 5 minutes. No root privileges are required as it uses user crontab.

attacks.description: Basic file download using CertUtil
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads text file from example.com to temp directory using certificate utility

attacks.description: Intermediate BITS transfer job
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates BITS job to download binary file from example.com to temp directory

attacks.description: Advanced PowerShell download with environment variable
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads executable from example.com using PowerShell to temp directory without IE parser dependencies

attacks.description: Download a benign payload using wget to /tmp/
attacks.expected_behavior: The benign payload is downloaded to /tmp/

attacks.description: Download a benign payload using curl to /tmp/
attacks.expected_behavior: The benign payload is downloaded to /tmp/

attacks.description: Silently download a benign payload and log success to /tmp/
attacks.expected_behavior: The benign payload is silently downloaded, and a success log is written to /tmp/download.log

attacks.command: copy "C:\Program Files\Oracle\jre\bin\jabswitch.exe" "%TEMP%\jabswitch.exe" & echo This is a benign placeholder for MuddyC2Go > "%TEMP%\oraociei18.dll" & "%TEMP%\jabswitch.exe"
attacks.description: Basic demonstration of DLL sideloading using jabswitch.exe with a spoofed Oracle DLL in the same directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Copies jabswitch.exe to %TEMP%, creates a benign fake DLL named oraociei18.dll (which jabswitch loads if present), and executes jabswitch.exe. The binary will run normally but load the spoofed DLL from the current directory.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "mkdir "%TEMP%\jab" -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue 2>nul && copy "C:\Program Files\Oracle\jre\bin\jabswitch.exe" "%TEMP%\jab\jabswitch.exe" && echo Simulated MuddyC2Go payload > "%TEMP%\jab\oraociei18.dll" && start "" "%TEMP%\jab\jabswitch.exe""
attacks.description: Intermediate approach using cmd.exe to create a dedicated directory and execute the sideloaded binary with clean separation.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a subdirectory in %TEMP%, copies jabswitch.exe, places a spoofed DLL, and launches the executable. Mimics real-world staging with minimal footprint. Uses only built-in tools and avoids PowerShell.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { $enc = [Convert]::ToBase64String([Text.Encoding]::Unicode.GetBytes('cmd.exe /c echo MuddyC2Go simulated execution & ping -n 5 127.0.0.1')); mkdir "$env:APPDATA\Oracle" -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; Set-Content -Path "$env:APPDATA\Oracle\jabswitch.exe" -Value (Get-Process -Id $PID).ProcessName -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; Set-Content -Path "$env:APPDATA\Oracle\oraociei18.dll" -Value "Base64:$enc" -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; Start-Process "$env:APPDATA\Oracle\jabswitch.exe" } catch { }"
attacks.description: Advanced simulation using PowerShell to encode a command, create spoofed files, and execute via sideloading in AppData.
attacks.expected_behavior: Uses PowerShell to simulate writing a benign encoded command into a fake DLL file, then executes the proxy binary. The fake files do not perform real malicious actions. Proper error suppression and directory creation are used. No .NET direct invocation; Start-Process is used safely.

attacks.description: Basic proxy execution using a staged shell script executed via /bin/sh (a signed system binary)
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a test script in /tmp, makes it executable, and runs it via /bin/sh. Expected result: /tmp/proxy_test.txt is created with 'test payload' content.

attacks.description: Intermediate: Use systemd-run (a signed systemd binary) to proxy execution of a shell command
attacks.expected_behavior: Uses systemd-run to execute a shell command that appends text to a log file. Runs in user scope; no persistence or damage expected.

attacks.description: Advanced: Abuse pkexec (a SUID binary) to proxy execution of a user-controlled script, simulating escalation via signed binary
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a script and attempts to run it via pkexec. Will prompt for password unless policy allows. Expected: /tmp/trigger.txt created with 'advanced trigger' if executed successfully. Risk is elevated due to privilege escalation attempt.

attacks.description: Basic system information discovery using the built‑in systeminfo utility.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs OS version, build number, system manufacturer, BIOS version, memory, and other host details to the console.

attacks.description: Intermediate discovery using the legacy wmic binary to query specific OS properties via WMI.
attacks.expected_behavior: Returns the OS name, version, build number, and architecture in a list format.

attacks.command: cmd /c "echo Dummy > %TEMP%\SimpleHelpSetup.exe && wmic process call create \"%TEMP%\SimpleHelpSetup.exe /quiet\""
attacks.description: Advanced example: creates a placeholder installer file and launches it via a WMI process creation call, emulating the observed SimpleHelp installer launch technique.
attacks.expected_behavior: Writes a dummy file named SimpleHelpSetup.exe to the temporary directory, then uses wmic to start the file with the /quiet argument. In a test environment the dummy file will be launched (which does nothing harmful).

attacks.description: Displays system information, including the kernel version and operating system release.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output a string containing the system's kernel version, hostname, and other details.

attacks.description: Prints operating system identification data.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will display the contents of the /etc/os-release file, providing information about the Linux distribution.

attacks.description: Displays Linux Standard Base (LSB) information about the distribution.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output detailed information about the Linux distribution, including the distributor, release, and codename.

attacks.description: Simulate silent execution of AnyDesk installer from the temp directory using built-in start command.
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to launch an executable named 'anydesk_installer.exe' in the user's temp directory with silent install flag. No actual payload is involved; this simulates initial execution stage of remote access tool.

attacks.description: Simulate hidden execution of SimpleHelp agent installer using PowerShell Start-Process.
attacks.expected_behavior: Launches cmd.exe to run a hypothetical SimpleHelp agent installer with install flag in hidden window. Requires admin rights for service installation. Uses only built-in PowerShell cmdlets and avoids .NET reflection.

attacks.description: Simulate persistence via Run key using built-in reg.exe to execute remote access tool on startup.
attacks.expected_behavior: Adds a registry entry to run 'simplehelp_agent.exe' with update argument at user logon. Uses built-in reg.exe and modifies HKCU, so no admin rights required. This emulates common persistence method used by remote access tools.

attacks.command: echo 'test remote access tool simulation' > /tmp/anydesk_sim && chmod +x /tmp/anydesk_sim && /tmp/anydesk_sim
attacks.description: Simulates basic execution of AnyDesk-like binary by creating and running an executable script
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a test script in /tmp, makes it executable, and runs it. Outputs a test string and exits.

attacks.command: echo '#!/bin/bash\necho \"SimpleHelp remote session started\"' > /tmp/simplehelp_agent.sh && chmod +x /tmp/simplehelp_agent.sh && nohup /tmp/simplehelp_agent.sh &
attacks.description: Simulates intermediate deployment of SimpleHelp agent via script executed in background
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a shell script simulating a SimpleHelp agent, makes it executable, and runs it in the background using nohup. Outputs session start message.

attacks.command:
echo '#!/bin/bash
echo "Remote access tool running detached"
sleep 30
echo "Session ending"
rm -f /tmp/rat_sim.sh' > /tmp/rat_sim.sh && chmod +x /tmp/rat_sim.sh && nohup /tmp/rat_sim.sh > /dev/null 2>&1 &
attacks.description: Simulates advanced execution of a remote access tool with backgrounding, delay, and self-cleanup
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a self-deleting script that runs in the background, simulates a remote session, waits 30 seconds, then removes itself. No persistent changes remain.

attacks.description: Establish a remote administrative connection to the C$ share using net.exe with supplied credentials
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a network connection to the remote administrative share. Will fail silently if credentials are invalid or share does not exist. No data exfiltration occurs.

attacks.command: sc.exe \\REMOTESYSTEM create TestService binPath= "cmd.exe /c echo test > %TEMP%\remoteservice_test.txt" start= auto
attacks.description: Create a service on a remote system using sc.exe to execute a benign command
attacks.expected_behavior: Deploys a service definition on the remote host. The service will write a test file upon start. Does not start the service automatically in this command.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Invoke-WmiMethod -Class Win32_Process -Name Create -ArgumentList 'cmd.exe /c echo WMI remote execution test > $env:TEMP\wmi_test.txt' -ComputerName REMOTESYSTEM"
attacks.description: Use WMI via PowerShell to execute a command remotely and create a test file
attacks.expected_behavior: Triggers remote command execution via WMI on REMOTESYSTEM. A file named wmi_test.txt is created in the remote TEMP directory with benign content.

attacks.description: Basic SSH command to execute 'id' on a remote host for user identification
attacks.expected_behavior: Connects to the remote host via SSH and runs the 'id' command, returning user and group information. Requires password input unless keys are set up.

attacks.description: Intermediate SSH command using a custom private key and disabled host key verification to authenticate remotely
attacks.expected_behavior: Uses a specified private key to authenticate without prompting for a password. Disables host key checking to bypass first-time connection prompts. Executes 'whoami' on the target.

attacks.command: mkdir -p /tmp/.ssh && cp /home/user/.ssh/id_rsa /tmp/.ssh/id_rsa_silent && chmod 600 /tmp/.ssh/id_rsa_silent && ssh -i /tmp/.ssh/id_rsa_silent -o UserKnownHostsFile=/dev/null -o StrictHostKeyChecking=no admin@10.0.0.5 'ps aux | head -5'
attacks.description: Advanced lateral movement using copied SSH key from local system to execute a process listing on a remote host with minimized logging and host verification
attacks.expected_behavior: Copies an existing SSH private key to a temporary hidden directory, sets correct permissions, and uses it to connect to a remote system. Runs a limited process listing. Uses options to reduce artifacts in known_hosts. Simulates stealthy lateral movement.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms; $path = '$env:TEMP\\keylog_test.txt'; $handler = { $key = [System.Windows.Forms.Control]::Focus().Focused; $keys = [System.Windows.Forms.Keys]::get_Modifiers(); if ($keys -ne 0) { $keys.ToString() + ' ' | Out-File -FilePath $path -Append -Encoding ASCII }; [System.Windows.Forms.Keys]::get_KeyData() | ForEach-Object { if ($_ -gt 0) { $_.ToString() | Out-File -FilePath $path -Append -Encoding ASCII } } }; Register-ObjectEvent -InputObject $global:timer -EventName Elapsed -Action $handler -SupportEvent; Start-Job -ScriptBlock { while($true) { Start-Sleep -Milliseconds 100; [System.Windows.Forms.Application]::DoEvents() } }; 'Keylogging simulation started.' } catch { Write-Error $_.Exception.Message }"
attacks.description: Basic keylogging simulation using System.Windows.Forms to capture key events and log to a temp file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a background job that simulates key capture by monitoring Windows Forms events and logs key data to a file in %TEMP%\keylog_test.txt. Runs in current user context without elevated privileges.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { $tempDir = [System.IO.Path]::GetTempPath(); $logPath = [System.IO.Path]::Combine($tempDir, 'input_capture.log'); $content = 'SIMULATED_KEYLOG_ENTRY: User typed text at $(Get-Date)' ; $content | Out-File -FilePath $logPath -Encoding ASCII -Append -Force } catch { Write-Error $_.Exception.Message }"
attacks.description: Intermediate simulation: Appends a benign test string to a log file in %TEMP% to mimic periodic input capture
attacks.expected_behavior: Simulates periodic input capture by appending a timestamped test string to input_capture.log in the system temp directory. No actual keystroke capture occurs. Safe for testing detection rules on file writes.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { $enc = ''; $taskAction = New-ScheduledTaskAction -Execute 'powershell.exe' -Argument '-EncodedCommand $enc'; $taskTrigger = New-ScheduledTaskTrigger -AtLogOn; $taskSettings = New-ScheduledTaskSettingsSet -ExecutionTimeLimit (New-TimeSpan -Minutes 10); $task = New-ScheduledTask -Action $taskAction -Trigger $taskTrigger -Settings $taskSettings; Register-ScheduledTask -TaskName 'InputCaptureSim' -InputObject $task -User $env:USERNAME -Force } catch { Write-Error $_.Exception.Message }"
attacks.description: Advanced simulation: Schedules a persistent task that periodically logs simulated input using encoded PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a scheduled task named 'InputCaptureSim' that runs at user logon, executing an encoded PowerShell command to simulate periodic input logging. Uses only built-in cmdlets and temporary paths. Simulates persistence and stealthy execution pattern.

attacks.description: Attempts to read raw input device events (e.g., keyboard) from /dev/input/event* files to simulate keylogging via device file access.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs hexdump of first 20 lines of raw input event data if accessible. Fails silently if no read permission or no device files present. Does not persist or exfiltrate data.

attacks.command: xinput list | grep -i keyboard | grep -o 'id=[0-9]*' | cut -d= -f2 | xargs -I {} xinput test {} --no-stop-icons 2>/dev/null | head -n 50
attacks.description: Uses xinput to identify keyboard devices and capture a limited number of input events in test mode, simulating user-level keylogging on X11.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists active keyboard devices, extracts their IDs, and captures up to 50 lines of input events (keystrokes) in real-time. Stops after 50 lines. No data is written to disk or exfiltrated.

attacks.command: exec 3< /proc/self/fd/0; while IFS= read -r -n1 -u3 char; do echo "[KEYLOG] $(date): '$char'" >> "$HOME/.keylog.tmp"; done
attacks.description: Simulates a simple keylogger by reading from stdin and logging each character to a temporary file in the user's home directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Reads each character typed in the current terminal session and appends a timestamped entry to ~/.keylog.tmp. Stops when the terminal is closed or interrupted. File is left for inspection but is benign and local.

attacks.command: wmic process call create "cmd.exe /c echo Hello > %TEMP%\test.txt"
attacks.description: Basic example of using WMI to create a new process that executes a command. This command creates a file named test.txt in the temp directory with the content 'Hello'.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new file named test.txt will be created in the temp directory with the content 'Hello'.

attacks.description: Intermediate example of using WMI to terminate a process. This command terminates all cmd.exe processes.
attacks.expected_behavior: All cmd.exe processes will be terminated.

attacks.description: Advanced example using PowerShell to interact with WMI and terminate processes. This command uses Get-WmiObject to find cmd.exe processes and then terminates them.
attacks.expected_behavior: All cmd.exe processes will be terminated.

attacks.command: wmic /node:localhost process call create "cmd.exe /c echo Hello > test.txt"
attacks.description: This command attempts to use wmic to create a new process on the local machine, simulating WMI execution. However, this requires a Windows environment to work directly and is included for conceptual understanding.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command would typically create a new file named test.txt with the content 'Hello' on a Windows system, demonstrating process creation via WMI. On Linux, without proper WMI support, this command would not execute as intended.

attacks.description: This command uses SSH to execute a command on the local machine, creating a file named test.txt. It demonstrates remote execution, akin to WMI's remote execution capabilities but using native Linux tools.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new file named test.txt is created in the user's home directory with the content 'Hello', demonstrating remote command execution.

attacks.description: This command uses the tee command to write 'Hello World' to both the standard output and a file named test.txt, demonstrating basic command execution and file creation.
attacks.expected_behavior: The string 'Hello World' is printed to the console and saved to a new file named test.txt, showing basic execution capabilities.

attacks.command: wmic process call create "cmd.exe /c echo WMI execution test > %TEMP%\wmi_test.txt"
attacks.description: Basic WMI process creation to execute a command and write output to a temporary file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a new process via WMI that runs cmd.exe, writes 'WMI execution test' to %TEMP%\wmi_test.txt, and exits. No elevated privileges needed for this basic execution.

attacks.command: wmic /namespace:\\root\cimv2 path Win32_Process get Name,ProcessId | findstr ".exe"
attacks.description: Intermediate WMI query to list running processes using native wmic.exe with filtering
attacks.expected_behavior: Queries the Win32_Process class to retrieve process names and IDs, then filters for '.exe' entries using findstr. This is a reconnaissance action that mimics attacker enumeration of running processes via WMI.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { $cmd = 'cmd.exe /c calc.exe'; $encoded = [Convert]::ToBase64String([Text.Encoding]::Unicode.GetBytes($cmd)); $wmiArgs = @{CommandLine = "powershell -EncodedCommand $encoded"}; Invoke-WmiMethod -Class Win32_Process -Name Create -ArgumentList $wmiArgs -ErrorAction Stop; } catch { exit 0 }"
attacks.description: Advanced WMI execution via PowerShell with encoded command to simulate obfuscated payload launch
attacks.expected_behavior: Uses PowerShell to encode a benign command (launch calc.exe) and executes it via WMI's Win32_Process.Create method. This simulates advanced obfuscation techniques while remaining safe. Errors are suppressed to avoid detection noise.

attacks.description: Lists all user accounts on the domain, which can be a precursor to credential dumping activities.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of user accounts in the domain.

attacks.description: Locates system files that contain credential information, which could be targeted for dumping.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists the paths of SAM, SECURITY, and SYSTEM files if accessible.

attacks.description: Lists all stored credentials in the Credential Manager, which can be a target for credential dumping.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of stored credentials and their associated information.

attacks.description: Retrieve user information including potential credentials
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays user information, potentially including encrypted passwords

attacks.description: Search for password entries in system configuration files
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists files and lines containing the word 'password'

attacks.description: Combine password and shadow files to extract credentials
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named credentials.txt containing combined user and password information

attacks.description: Lists all running services on the local machine
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of Windows services that are currently running

attacks.description: Displays active network connections and listening ports with process IDs
attacks.expected_behavior: Shows network statistics including TCP/UDP connections and associated process identifiers

attacks.description: Lists extended information about all services including stopped ones
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs detailed service configuration information for all services regardless of state

attacks.description: Perform service version detection on common ports (SSH, HTTP, HTTPS) on localhost
attacks.expected_behavior: Scans specified ports on localhost and reports open services and their versions. Minimal network impact, limited to local machine.

attacks.description: Use netcat to scan for open ports in the 20-80 range on a common local gateway IP
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts TCP connections to ports 20-80 on 192.168.1.1. Reports which ports are open. Non-invasive and limited to local subnet.

attacks.description: List all listening network sockets on the local system using the ss command
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of open TCP and UDP ports on the local machine, showing services bound to interfaces. No network traffic generated; reads kernel state.

attacks.description: Basic: Archive a test document into CAB using makecab
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a CAB file (archive.cab) in %TEMP% containing the specified document.

attacks.description: Intermediate: Compress application logs into ZIP archive
attacks.expected_behavior: Zips all .log files from AppData into logs.zip in TEMP, overwriting existing files with -Force.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Set-Content -Path $env:TEMP\test.txt -Value 'test data'; Compress-Archive -Path $env:TEMP\test.txt -DestinationPath $env:TEMP\collection.zip -Force; certutil -encode $env:TEMP\collection.zip $env:TEMP\collection.b64; Remove-Item $env:TEMP\collection.zip -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue"
attacks.description: Advanced: Create test file, archive, encode with certutil, and clean up
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates a test file, compresses it to ZIP, encodes to Base64 via certutil, and deletes the ZIP. Uses -Force for compression and ErrorAction for cleanup.

attacks.description: Basic archiving of collected data using tar
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a compressed archive of the specified data

attacks.description: Intermediate archiving using find and tar for more complex data collection
attacks.expected_behavior: Archives files found by the find command, handling file names with spaces safely

attacks.description: Advanced archiving with directory change to ensure relative paths are preserved
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates an archive of the data directory, preserving the directory structure

attacks.description: Basic download of file using certutil (common phishing payload retrieval method)
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads test.txt from example.com to TEMP directory using Windows utility

attacks.description: Intermediate LNK file creation with embedded command execution
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates shortcut file in TEMP that writes test message when executed

attacks.description: Advanced encoded PowerShell command writing test file
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes base64-encoded command to write test message to TEMP directory

attacks.command: echo 'Please enter your credentials: ' > phishing.txt; cat phishing.txt
attacks.description: Basic phishing attempt by creating a file asking for credentials
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named phishing.txt with a message asking for credentials and then displays the message.

attacks.description: Intermediate phishing attempt by downloading a potentially malicious script
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a script from a specified URL, saves it to the user's home directory, and makes it executable.

attacks.command: python3 -c 'import smtplib; server = smtplib.SMTP("smtp.example.com", 587); server.starttls(); server.login("phisher@example.com", "password"); server.sendmail("phisher@example.com", "victim@example.com", "Subject: Phishing Email\n\nPlease click this link: http://example.com/malicious_link"); server.quit()'
attacks.description: Advanced phishing attempt by sending a phishing email using Python
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends a phishing email with a malicious link to a victim's email address.

attacks.description: Create daily scheduled task as SYSTEM to append test message to TEMP log
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates task that runs daily at midnight, writing to %TEMP%\log.txt

attacks.description: Create logon-triggered task as SYSTEM user
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates task executing on user logon, appending to TEMP log

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$t1 = New-ScheduledTaskTrigger -AtLogOn; $t2 = New-ScheduledTaskTrigger -Daily -At 03:00; Register-ScheduledTask -TaskName 'AdvancedTask' -Trigger @($t1,$t2) -Action (New-ScheduledTaskAction -Execute 'cmd.exe' -Argument '/c echo test >> %TEMP%\log.txt') -Description 'Test task'"
attacks.description: Create multi-trigger scheduled task via PowerShell (logon + daily)
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates task that triggers on user logon and daily at 3 AM

attacks.description: Creates a user-level cron job that runs every minute, appending a test message to a log file.
attacks.expected_behavior: A cron job is installed for the current user that executes a bash command every minute, writing a timestamped message to /tmp/cron_test.log.

attacks.description: Adds a registry entry to run calc.exe at user login using reg.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: The Windows Registry key HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run will have a new value named 'Updater' pointing to calc.exe. Calculator will launch automatically at next user login.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to set a registry Run key with a command to launch notepad.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: A new registry value 'CloudSync' is created under HKCU Run key. At next login, cmd.exe will execute with argument '/c notepad.exe', opening Notepad.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$cmd = 'cmd.exe /c echo Hello Persistence ^&^& notepad.exe'; $bytes = [System.Text.Encoding]::Unicode.GetBytes($cmd); $encoded = [Convert]::ToBase64String($bytes); $value = "powershell.exe -EncodedCommand $encoded"; Set-ItemProperty -Path 'HKCU:\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run' -Name 'UpdaterSvc' -Value $value -ErrorAction Stop"
attacks.description: Sets a registry Run key with an encoded PowerShell command to simulate obfuscated execution
attacks.expected_behavior: A registry value 'UpdaterSvc' is added under HKCU Run key containing a Base64-encoded command. At next login, PowerShell will decode and execute a command that echoes a message and launches Notepad.

attacks.description: Appends a check and execution of a script in the user's bashrc file to achieve persistence on shell login.
attacks.expected_behavior: On each interactive shell login, the system checks for ~/.malicious and executes it if present. This mimics registry run keys by ensuring user-level persistence without requiring root.

attacks.command:
echo '[Unit]
Description=Malicious Persistence
[Service]
ExecStart=/bin/sh /root/.malicious
RemainAfterExit=yes
[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target' > /etc/systemd/system/malicious-persistence.service && systemctl daemon-reload && systemctl enable malicious-persistence.service
attacks.description: Installs a systemd service that runs a script at boot, achieving system-wide persistence similar to a registry run key.
attacks.expected_behavior: After reboot, the systemd service executes the script located at /root/.malicious. This provides root-level persistence and survives reboots, mimicking machine-wide registry run keys.

attacks.description: Initiate an RDP connection to a target machine.
attacks.expected_behavior: An RDP connection attempt to the specified target machine will be initiated.

attacks.description: Enable RDP connections by modifying the registry.
attacks.expected_behavior: RDP connections will be enabled on the target machine by changing the registry setting.

attacks.description: Check the current RDP connection setting via PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: The current value of the fDenyTSConnections registry key will be retrieved, indicating whether RDP connections are allowed or denied.

attacks.description: Basic RDP connection to a remote desktop
attacks.expected_behavior: Establishes a basic RDP connection to the specified remote desktop

attacks.description: Intermediate RDP connection with specified screen size
attacks.expected_behavior: Establishes an RDP connection with a specified screen size

attacks.description: Advanced RDP connection ignoring certificate warnings
attacks.expected_behavior: Establishes an RDP connection while ignoring certificate warnings, which could be risky in production environments
